data.title: Castle with that 'lived in' look The Earl and Countess of Glasgow show DOUGLAS CRAWFORD round some of the more private aspects of their ancestral home in Ayrshire, Kelburn Castle.
data.meta_description: ''I LIKE a certain amount of austerity -- goes rather well with the
data.text:
Isabel, Countess of Glasgow, about Kelburn Castle, ancestral home of the

earls of Glasgow since 1700 and of their forebears for long centuries

before that.

''In fact,'' added her husband Patrick, the tenth earl, ''the castle

has been inhabited for as long as anybody can remember and it's been

only natural that everyone who's lived here has impressed their own

character, their own taste, on the trappings of the house.''

It is this more than anything else that contributes an atmosphere of

the castle as somewhere that has very much been -- and very much still

is, I would emphasise -- ''lived in.'' And for me the family photographs

on the escritoire in the great drawing room, the teddy bears on its

window-sill, the Bechstein piano with the words Hof Lieferant Sr Maj des

Kaisers u Konigs inscribed on the underside of its lid, the books in the

cabinets throughout, all testify to a continuity of this sense of place.

There has been a castle at Kelburn -- set in rolling parkland south of

the Hailie Brae between Largs and Fairlie and with a spectacular view

from the north Ayrshire coast across the Firth of Clyde to the Cumbraes

and the island of Arran -- since the thirteenth century. The land on

which it stands has belonged to the Boyle family since that time and has

descended to the present owner in the direct line of male succession.

Architecturally, it is an agglomeration of four contrasting styles.

The earliest (thirteenth century) part is a square keep (''I like the

tiny bedrooms off its turret, don't you?'' said Lady Glasgow as she ever

so slightly bent her head to lead me into one of them) around which was

built a James VI tower house in the 1580s.

Here today, as everywhere else in the castle, it is clear that hardly

a single square foot is wasted. Every room is functional. Bedrooms are

very much bedrooms and bathrooms very much bathrooms. Of the latter the

countess observed: ''I had iron bars installed on the heating rails in

them rather than plastic bars, simply to keep the fittings in concert

with the 'feel' of the house overall.''

The greatest glory of Kelburn for the visitor, however, is the

William-and-Mary addition that was built, as the seventeenth century

merged with the eighteenth, at an angle to the earlier thirteenth and

sixteenth-century towers. A line of baroque state rooms marches behind a

facade designed in what was to be one of the last vestiges of Scottish

tower house vernacular. Over the door to its centrepiece -- the great

drawing room -- stands a pediment and on this pediment is the

information that the room was completed in 1700.

The motif of the cornices is an entwining of the thistle and the rose

clearly designed to anticipate the forthcoming union of the two

parliaments of Scotland and England in 1707.

Although a trifle premature, there was political method behind this

idea. David Boyle, during whose time the work was carried out, was one

of those who pushed the Act of Union through a not altogether unanimous

Scottish Parliament, for which he was rewarded with his elevation to

become the first Earl of Glasgow.

Of his achievement at Kelburn, it has been said that ''Lord Glasgow

cobbled together and drilled into symmetry a reworking of such

traditional elements as crow-stepped gables, chimneys, and a heraldic

panel over the principal door.

''To give an ornamental flourish, the prosaic rain-water pipe became

an extravaganza in leadwork. Although it divides, in order to preserve

the necessary symmetry, it seems to owe more to heraldry than

architecture and culminates in a three-dimensional and rather dotty

double-headed eagle over the entrance -- a spirited rendering of the

family crest. These marked architectural failings, however, are the

source of its very considerable charm.''

The subsequent addition of the Victorian, or ''dining room'' wing in

the nineteenth century is typical of its period: the Raeburn portraits;

the wrought-iron hinges on the new front door; the choice of grates

fitted to old chimney pieces; the light fittings. Here too is the

epitome of Victoriana -- the original William Morris wallpaper with its

acanthus design and the Morris curtains with their tulip montage.

Kelburn Castle has 50 rooms in all, eight of these being bedrooms with

private bathrooms and eight being bedrooms without such additions. One

of the fixtures that Lady Glasgow has been anxious to retain throughout

the building is the claw-foot wrought-iron baths in preference to

anything more ''modern,'' which she feels would be out of harmony with

the building's overall surroundings.

For me one of the nicest vignettes of the castle and its surroundings

stands at a stone's throw to the south-west of the main buildings. It is

a delightful little square box garden that the third earl had planted in

1769 in the shape of the St Andrew's Cross and with his children's

initials (G for George, E for Elizabeth, H for Helen, and J for Jane)

planted in miniature hedges at the inside corner of each of the four

individual enclosed gardens.

The whole estate of the Glasgows stretches for 35 acres over the

hillside and comprises two farms, one lowland and the other hill. Both

are at present sheep farms, but the intention is to convert the lower to

mixed grazing.

In 1977 the Kelburn Country Centre was opened and the south side of

the park is now available to the general public between April and

September of each year, with a wide range of facilities for recreation,

including pony trekking, a pets corner, and an assault course. There are

also a museum and various exhibitions, a potter's workshop, a craftshop

and a tearoom, neatly created out of the old 1700 farm buildings.

Kelburn is renowned for its rare and unusual trees, including the

largest Monterey pine in Scotland, two yew trees that are both more than

1000 years old, and an extraordinary weeping larch.

The castle itself, however, is open to the public for only five weeks

after Easter each year, and thousands of tours are conducted around it

and through all its state rooms and its nooks and crannies.

For the rest? Kelburn Castle remains what it has been for much of its

history over more than seven centuries -- the home of the Boyle family,

their friends, and their relations.
